column4: quick question: I want my /dev/sda1 to be mount at /boot and my /dev/sda2 to be mounted at / . Which of those partition must be marked as bootable?
obviously? grub will be on /dev/sda's MBR. Why should it matter?
the MBR has nothing to do with where you mount partitions
but GRUB does. BIOS reads and load MBR, where GRUB lives. Grub kicks in and loads whatever stated in menu.cfg. So why should the partition "boot" flag matter?
why should the partition mounted as /boot be flagged as "boot"  and not the partition mounted at / considering that GRUB is installed properly
because the /boot partition is where the kernel image is stored..Without it, you cant boot
then the bootloader knows what to boot from where with total disregard of partition flags....
though I could be wrong on top of a little bit obnoxious though
then the partition "boot" flash should not matter.
if that is the case then the partition "boot" flash should not matter.
if that is the case then the partition "boot" flag should not matter.
Ubuntu should take care of boot flags and all of that for you.
just mount the /boot partition on the drive you want and the / to the other.  But I am not sure why in the world you want a whole drive dedicated to the tiny /boot partition
